channel.title: Maths
channel.description:
Well, I forgot how to calculate this:
(example)
You have a lock on your bike. It is one of those numeric locks where there is a code wich you need to know in order to unlock it. There are a total of 4 numbers to know, and they range from 0 to 9. Now the question is, how many possible codes are possible? Is it just 10x10x10x10? Or 10^4 (wich is the same)
Thanks in advance.

item.title: Maths
item.dc:creator: @davidude36 Brolapse
item.description:
@davidude36 wrote:

its 9 to the power of 4 i believe… not really sure tbh.

it would be 9 X 9 (because 9 different digits)
Then 81 X 81 (9 x 9 = 81)
and 6561 x 6561
finally 43,046,721

So 43 million different combination i got. A tad different to the 184 posted above lol.

offtopic - i managed to crack my friends bike lock which was 4 digits by trying a method i saw on youtube.

Oh wait if 0 is also used in this lock of yours then it would start of as 10 and follow the rule above basically.

10 X 10
100 X 100
10,000 X 10,000
100,000,000
one hundred million different combinations.

edit again - no this cannot be right =/ id just say there are going to be 9999 different combinations.

Read full topic

item.title: Maths
item.dc:creator: @Diablo_II Diablo II
item.description:
@Diablo_II wrote:

MUHUHAHAHA! I got the wrong anwser! (I had the anwser here but I’m not an idiot so I’m keeping what I got private :P)
